title: 115_hr6439
content: The Act titled "Biometric Identification Transnational Migration Alert Program Authorization Act of 2018" introduces the Biometric Identification Transnational Migration Alert Program under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. This program aims to enhance border security through biometric identification measures. The Biometric Identification Transnational Migration Alert Program (BITMAP) is established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to address national security, border security, and terrorist threats before reaching the US border. The program involves coordinating with foreign governments to share biometric and biographic information for identifying potential threats. The Biometric Identification Transnational Migration Alert Program (BITMAP) aims to provide capabilities and equipment to partner countries for collecting biometric and biographic data to identify and prevent high-risk individuals posing national security, border security, or terrorist threats. This includes comparing foreign data with US security databases like the FBI's Terrorist Screening Database. The Biometric Identification Transnational Migration Alert Program (BITMAP) aims to provide partner countries with capabilities and equipment for collecting biometric and biographic data to identify high-risk individuals. This includes accessing databases such as the Terrorist Screening Database, FBI's Next Generation Identification database, Department of Defense's ABIS, Department's IDENT, and other designated databases. Additionally, partner countries receive training and guidance. The Biometric Identification Transnational Migration Alert Program (BITMAP) provides partner countries with training, guidance, and best practices for enrolling individuals in BITMAP. It ensures that collected biometric and biographic data are incorporated into US Government databases. The Secretary collaborates with relevant Department components and other Federal agencies as needed. Before operating in a new partner country, agreements must be made in consultation with the Secretary of State. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of State, will enter into agreements with partner countries for the Biometric Identification Transnational Migration Alert Program (BITMAP). Before operations begin in a new country, the Secretary must notify Congress 60 days in advance. The Secretary must provide details on foreign country agreements, operation locations, goals, and personnel terms for BITMAP operations. Any data of US citizens captured must be expunged unless needed for law enforcement or intelligence purposes. A report on BITMAP must be submitted within 180 days. The Biometric Identification Transnational Migration Alert Program (BITMAP) is established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit an annual report to Congress detailing BITMAP's effectiveness in enhancing national security, border security, and counterterrorism operations. The report outlines strategic goals, operational plans, efforts with partner countries, agreements with partner governments, and budget information. The annual report on BITMAP includes budget information, department support details by country, enrollment numbers from partner countries, training and best practices recommendations, redress process review, and effectiveness in enhancing national security and border security. The Secretary of Homeland Security shall brief congressional committees on individuals enrolled in BITMAP who have been apprehended and asylum claims. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct audits on the effectiveness of BITMAP operations every 3 years. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct audits on the effectiveness of BITMAP operations and submit a report to congressional committees. Section 447 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 will be repealed 6 years after the enactment of this Act. Section 447 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002, titled Biometric Identification Transnational Migration Alert Program, will be repealed 6 years after the enactment of this Act.
